reviewText: This is a superb film, giving the viewer a great story of a little known period of American history. The battle/skirmish scenes with the Apache were well done and very realistic. I did not let the automobile approaching in the distance in one of the scenes at Fort Craig put me off either.Glad I bought this DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Buffalo Soldiers was the name given to Colored soldiers by Indians because their hair resembled that of buffaloes.This movie takes place shortly after the end of the Civil War, when former slaves were given their freedom.Colored soldiers served in the West fight the Indians.Being discriminated against and not accepted as men is a given for the times.When the Buffalo Soldiers surround an Apache band, they are ordered to kill all, even women and children.  An Apache chief asks them how they can follow the orders of their former slave masters.The soldiers show compassion and let the Indians escape.  The Apache show these soldiers respect when at the same time their army does not.The racism and segregation shown is this movie to Glory, to the Tuskegee Airmen, to Vietnam, to now still exists.

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie about the "Buffalo Soldiers". Not sure how accurate it was to the real Buffalo Soldiers story. However, it is still a part of our history. Danny Glover did a great job portraying an Army officer, he is a great actor. It had to be tough during this time of our history dealing with the pressure always being treated less than the white officers of equal rank and fighting the enemy all at the same time. I enjoyed the scenery of the ole west. Thanks to the actors involved in making this film. The movie was entertaining; I just wish it had some extras like the making of Buffalo Soldiers.  It was well worth watching for me because I am fan of westerns.
summary: Great Movie about the Buffalo Soldiers

reviewText: Great movie and was so when TNT did it for TV.  Danny Glover was very good in this part and since I was, and am now a life memeber of the 1st Cavalry Division, I know a lot about the 9th and 10th Cav units who were the Buffalo Soldiers.  I mysef served with the Delta Co. 2nd Bat 8th Cav Rgt Abn 1st Air Cavalry Div. Vietnam 68/69, so I love everything Cav, including all the John Wayne Cav movies.  We have a steep tradition in the Cav, that goes very deep!  God Bless the CAV!!!  Nick Donvito.

reviewText: As an African-American I am interested in movies about Black history, Black culture, and life during slavery and historical black events.As a result I purchased about a dozen DVDs on various subject matter which I am just now getting around to viewing.I had heard about Buffalo soldiers but was not aware of the kind of role they played in history.This DVD gave me more insight into who they were, what kind of role they played in settling the West and a general background on how they fared with their white counterparts coming after the civil war.A good overall movie.

reviewText: Danny Glover tends to piss folks off by making relevant movies. The Buffalo soldiers under civil war hero Col. Benjamin Grierson (see the John Wayne movie the Horse Soldiers) helped to subjugate our native American brothers & sisters. And I have a REAL problem with that. What did they hope to gain? Respect? Equality? Under General Sherman? This movie hits ALL these sore points. Every kid in America should see this motion picture. Then remember after dying along side Teddy Roosevelt on San Juan Hill (see the movie Rough Riders) the Buffalo Soldiers were disarmed in WWI & dishonored & disbanded in Korea. How quickly heroes & their sacrifice are forgotten.

reviewText: Few movies have been made about black soldiers serving in the West after the civil war.  One other notable is "Sergeant Rutledge", starring Woody Strode. The movie details, how in spite of the discrimination they must endure, black troopers, many ex-slaves, led by Glover suffer battle losses, the intolerance of their superior officers, and the humiliation of having to dismount and walk rather than ride through the nearby white town, all while they battle the local Apache warrior tribe. Ironically, in the end, they find that they cannot bring themselves to inflict the same brutality on the Apache families  that many of them had experienced themselves. If you want a glimpse of what black calvary life was like, I recommend this movie plus  "Sergeant Rutledge."
summary: A rare look at black union calvary in the post civil war West
